HEALTH EQUITY & DISPARITIES
IN A 21st CENTURY PANDEMIC

In March of 2020, New York Stateâ€™s Gov. Andrew Cuomo charged the University at Albany with leading a team of public health, social welfare, emergency preparedness and other experts from both research and practice in a study of the environmental, socioeconomic, and occupational factors causing Latinx and Black individuals in the state to be disproportionately harmed by COVID-19. See www.albany.edu/mhd.

In pursing this charge, the Vice President for Research at the University at Albany, Dr. James Dias partnered with fellow VPRs from SUNY Downstate Health Sciences University, Dr. David Christini, and SUNY Upstate Medical University, Dr. David Amberg, to strengthen existing partnerships and build new research and practice collaborations focused on health equity. As part of their joint efforts, the VPRs are launching this multi-campus conversation including researchers and community partners focused on advancing knowledge and building new understanding of minority health disparities in a 21st century pandemic. The overarching aim of this event it to inform the development of a relevant, robust, and action-oriented shared health equity research agenda.

This important conversation will be carried out over a series of three virtual sessions held on successive Fridays in January 2021 beginning on January 8, 2021, and ending on Friday, January 22, 2021. Each event is scheduled to begin at 10:00am and will be held on Zoom.

Thank you in advance for being part of this important conversation and for contributing to the development of an ongoing and shared health equity research agenda focused on understanding and eliminating health disparities.
